docs.lead_paragraph: A pair of unlikely partners, hospitals and the people who work for them, announced yesterday that they had banded together to explore an unusual and ambitious goal: the takeover of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the huge insurance company that has traditionally cared for the sickest New Yorkers. The regulatory hurdles to such a plan, which is at its earliest stage, would be enormous and perhaps unscalable. But health care experts said the proposal represented a bold effort by the medical industry to regain control of its financial destiny, after years of being squeezed by managed care insurance companies and vastly increased competition.

headline.main: Hospitals and Unions Propose Takeover of Empire Blue Cross

docs.abstract: Unlikely coalition of New York hospitals and hospital workers announces proposal to take over Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield in bold effort by the medical industry to regain control of its financial destiny; leading proponents of the plan are Kenneth E Raske, executive director of Greater New York Hospital Assn, and Dennis Rivera, president of 1199 National Health and Human Service Employees Union (M)

keywords.value: NATIONAL HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICE EMPLOYEES UNION

docs.lead_paragraph: As the debate begins over the agreement to reduce global gas emissions, many Republicans sense that they have a political opportunity reminiscent of the health care fight of 1994. The country then supported the basic idea of health insurance for all, just as it now supports strong environmental action. But Republicans skewered the health plan on the details, and in the process painted President Clinton as a big-government liberal. Some now think they can repeat their success and this time tar Vice President Al Gore.

headline.main: G.O.P. Hopes Climate Fight Echoes Health Care Outcome

docs.abstract: Republicans hope to turn agreement to reduce global emissions of greenhouse gases into a weapon to use against Vice Pres Al Gore, portraying it as an unprecedented government seizure of American freedom and sovereignty; note that while public supports strong environmental action, it also supported the basic idea of health insurance for all in 1994 but was nevertheless brought around to see Pres Clinton's health plan as the work of a big-government liberal; others in party urge caution, recalling how Republicans have often fallen on wrong side in environmental debate; Republican opportunity is enhanced by division between Democrats' environmental and labor constituencies (M)
docs.snippet: As the debate begins over the agreement to reduce global gas emissions, many Republicans sense that they have a political opportunity reminiscent of the health care fight of 1994.    The country then supported the basic idea of health insurance for...

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Edward M. Kennedy called upon Democrats today to use the nation's economic vigor to help struggling families secure higher wages, good educations and basic health care. The Senator from Massachusetts scoffed at reports of a rift between the House Democratic leader, Richard A. Gephardt, and President Clinton, saying the party's internal differences were trivial compared to its differences with the Republicans.

headline.main: Kennedy Presses Democrats to Focus on the Needs of Families

docs.abstract: Sen Edward M Kennedy, speaking at National Press Club, urges Democrats to use nation's economic vigor to help struggling families secure higher wages, good educations and basic health care (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: While presiding over child neglect cases here last year, Judge Nicolette M. Pach of Family Court was struck that most of the parents were struggling with drug or alcohol abuse. So she dashed off a memo to a supervisor suggesting a special court to deal with the problem. She proposed that the court put the parents in closely monitored drug treatment programs, aiming for rehabilitation, employment and family reunification. Failing that, she said, the children should be spared from revolving-door foster care and placed for adoption in permanent new homes.

headline.main: A Court Aims at Roots of Child Neglect

docs.abstract: a court aims at roots of child neglect**Judge Nicolette M Pach to begin hearing cases in new Family Drug Treatment Court of Suffolk County, NY; court, proposed by Pach, is nation's first to specialize in drug and alcohol abuse in child neglect cases; Chief Judge Judith Kaye inaugurates court (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Miriam Martinez has a fierce, fighting spirit. She says it comes from living through the loss of her husband, the one true love of her life, whom she nursed round the clock until his death 10 years ago after a long illness. That strength, she says, is what has seen her through the recent diagnosis of breast cancer at age 41, and the mastectomy, chemotherapy and radiation that accompanied it. She likens the experience now to a bad dream, although she says it woke her up and made her treasure life.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; After Mastectomy, an Accelerated Life

docs.abstract: Miriam Martinez, who battles breast cancer, comments on help she has gotten from agencies sponsored by New York Times Neediest Cases Fund; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Pay no attention, said Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont, to all that high political gossip about how he purportedly told Vice President Al Gore last week that he planned to use this bucolic state as a launching pad to the White House. He has not, repeat not, decided to run for President in 2000, Dr. Dean said this week in an interview. But watch this space. (This space being Montpelier, the only state capital to boast that it has no McDonald's and the seat of power in a state both stubbornly wedded to tradition and so socially progressive that it often acts as a laboratory for the rest of the country.)

headline.main: No, Says the Vermont Chief, He Is No Gore Threat (Yet)

docs.abstract: Vermont Gov Howard Dean says he plans to seek re-election next year and will decide in 1999 whether to seek Presidency; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Already down, the stock of Oxford Health Plans, the troubled managed care company, was battered again yesterday. Following the company's announcement late Tuesday, after last week's silence, that its medical costs continued to be higher than expected and that it would report an estimated net loss of $120 million in the coming quarter, the stock plummeted 15 percent, or nearly $3, to close at $17.125. Earlier in the day, it had sold for about $16, a low that it had not seen for almost three years.

headline.main: Market Place; Oxford Health Share Price Takes Another Beating

docs.abstract: Market Place: Stock of Oxford Health Plans is battered again; stock plummets 15 percent, or nearly $3, to close at $17.125; while stock's decline has convinced some that Oxford is a bargain, many investors and analysts are worried that company could be in for a worse beating; stock has bled more than three-quarters of its value from its all-time high of $89 in July; graph (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: New York State has canceled plans to award a $350 million contract to a health care company after a state inspector general's report said a state worker may have rigged bids. ''We found the specter of personal bias by one evaluator'' throughout ''the evaluation process,'' Inspector General Roslyn Mauskopf said in a letter to State Comptroller H. Carl McCall.

headline.main: Question on Bid Scuttles Plan On Health Care

docs.abstract: New York State cancels plans to award $350 million contract to health care company after state inspector general's report found that a state worker may have rigged bids; Times-Union of Albany reports that state employee funneled information to Value Health of Avon, Conn, and designed specifications insuring that company would land contract (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: JAPAN'S financial system, built around giant banks with fingers in every economic pie, is collapsing along with real estate and stock markets -- and in the process dragging Japan to the brink of depression. Why, then, should America abandon the legal barricades that have separated banking from other financial services and inhibited the rise of nationwide branch banking since the New Deal? The next time the White House tries to maneuver comprehensive banking reform past a skeptical Congress -- a futile exercise for the last two Administrations -- the Treasury will have to come up with convincing answers. Check that; it already has.

headline.main: Economic Scene; A new look at bank reforms to cut inefficiencies and risk.

docs.abstract: Economic Scene column on US Treasury Department report, American Finance for the 21st Century, which summarizes where financial services industry has been and compellingly argues for where it ought to go; report's recommendations for reforming banking industry discussed; drawing (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans, a managed care company that enjoyed running advertisements questioning why competitors were not matching its consumer-friendly brand of health care, acknowledged yesterday that it had sorely underestimated the cost of that care. Under pressure from the New York State Department of Insurance, Oxford confirmed fears yesterday that it had misjudged its costs, with the announcement that it would take a substantial charge to fourth-quarter earnings and show a loss for the year. It described the insurance department's review of it as ''continuing.''

headline.main: Oxford Says It Misjudged Cost of Care

docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans, a managed care company, acknowledges that it sorely underestimated cost of its health care; under pressure from New York State Department of Insurance, Oxford confirmed fears that it misjudged its costs, with announcement that it will take substantial charge to fourth-quarter earnings and show loss for the year; full size of charge is not disclosed, but at least $164 million of it will go just to bolster reserves for medical claims submitted on behalf of New York policyholders, core of its business (L)
docs.snippet: Oxford Health Plans, a managed care company that enjoyed running advertisements questioning why competitors were not matching its consumer-friendly brand of health care, acknowledged yesterday that it had sorely underestimated the cost of that care. ...
